data.text: @EvanSelinger 2) mask efficacy has often been reduced to a pure observation question. As if predictive interventions are not theory-laden projection with lots of auxiliary assumptions. Maybe this suggests an effort to over-simplify as a way of making it just a political choice?

@EvanSelinger 1) Consider that: red and blue cities are not 100% red or blue; infection rates were aggregated by lot not political affiliation; variance in testing and reporting not tracked. The data is super messy but he’s trying to derive a linear political relation from just the data. And…
@BrendaKLeong Absolutely, but you’d think that would be reflected in the analysis.

@EvanSelinger I mean yes, of course - but also, has that ever been reflected in “wears masks” data? Haven’t masks always been lumped, despite differences in effectiveness, simply because there’s no way to collect it more granularly? (While acknowledging healthcare has always worn better)

@BrendaKLeong Yes but back to my original question. The author just talks about “masks” and doesn’t differentiate between types. In fact, he can’t based on simply comparing infection rate numbers and adjusting for geography. Doesn’t this limit make it hard to draw any significsnt conclusions

@EvanSelinger economic cost of continuing the restrictions or even just social practices of distancing, masks, and less going out, are not the only costs. Dense areas have more high risk (sm children; disabled) and may or want need longer period to rebalance.
